Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale Computational Methods for Semiclassical Schrodinger Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposer proposes to develop efficient numerical methods
for several problems in quantum dynamics. Specifically, the following
three topics are selected: Semiclassical methods for quantumscattering,
surface hopping, and Bloch-decomposition based computational
methods for quantum dynamics in periodic lattice. These are challenging
computational issues that involve high frequency waves and
quantum-classical coupling. Mathematical and computational
methods can play important roles to enhance our understanding as well
as our ability to simulate these problems.

These problems arise in solid state physics, semiconductor device
modeling, Bose-Eistein Condensations (BEC), solar energy, and
functional materials such as graphane, thus the developed computational
methods will have a wide range of applications, some of which of
significant national interests. Some of the research results will
provide excellent additions for future graduate courses in applied
mathematics and scientific computing, thus will help to
improve the graduate curriculum in applied mathematics in order to
better train future graduate students in modern applied mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits: Numerical simulations at quantum level is notoriously challenging due to the high dimensionality of the problem and high frequency nature of the wave function.  Semiclassical methods provide a viable tool with the computational cost much less than the quantum simulation but can still describe important quantum phenomena that one desires to capture.  The PI made significant advances in developing several important semiclassical computational methods. Specificially, the PI  developed Gaussian beam methods for Schrodinger and Wigner equations with discontinuous potentials;  he also developed semiclassical models for systems of Schrodinger equations, and Schrodinger equations with periodic potentials, to account for non-adiabatic phenomenon that arises due to band crossing, an important phenomenon in surface hopping and semiconductor modeling, and chemical reactions. These new numerical results and mathematical models allow one to efficiently compute non-adiabatic quantum phenomena such as quantum tunneling, chemical reaction, Berry connections etc. with the computational cost of semiclassical mechanics. The PI also extended these robust and efficient algorithms for high frequency polzrized waves which are important in elastic and electromagnetic waves.


Broad impact:  These research results have broad impact in important technology areas such as semiconductor device, graphene, seismology, and quantum chemistry. The PI also trained a number of excellent Ph.D. students who found postdoc or tenure-track positions at prominent academic institutions. such as Stanford, Caltech, UCLA, Texas-Austin, etc.
